item.title: 20161021 UT MAT157/MAT240: Preparation for Study Session III
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I am extremely grateful to all of you who have come today and made the session productive.

It has been a pleasure to study in the environment full of initiative and support. Thanks to all of you who have asked questions, dared to be confused and took a risk of showing what and how they think in front of a dozen of peers.

I hope you have found something useful in the session today. If not, it would be great to hear what might have been done better. And the suggestions of interesting topics or problems you may wish to add to the agenda in the future are hugely welcomed!

Following the discussion of the Nested Interval Theorem, which turns out to be a consequence of Cantor's Intersection Theorem, here is the problem from Spivak with which the Intermediate Value Theorem can be proven differently from how it has been done in class:

Suppose $$f$$ is continuous on $$[a, b]$$ and $$f(a) < 0 < f(b)$$.

Then either $$f(\frac{a + b}{2}) = 0$$, or $$f$$ has different signs at the end points of $$[a, \frac{a+b}{2}]$$, or $$f$$ has different signs at the end points of $$[\frac{a + b}{2}, b]$$.

Why?

If $$f(\frac{a + b}{2}) \neq 0$$, let $$I_1$$ be one of the two intervals on which $$f$$ changes sign. Now bisect $$I_1$$. Either $$f$$ is $$0$$ at the midpoint, or $$f$$ changes sign on one of the two intervals. Let $$I_2$$ be such an interval. Continue in this way, to define $$I_n$$ for each $$n$$ (unless $$f$$ is $$0$$ at some midpoint). Use the Nested Interval Theorem to find a point $$x$$ where $$f(x) = 0$$.

I hope you have a refreshing weekend.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: 20161021 UT MAT157/MAT240: Study Session II
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I am writing to remind you that we are planning to meet today at 16:10 in B026 (seminar room), Bahen.

As we have decided earlier, the session is going to be split into two, one devoted to LA, and one to RA.

I would be extremely grateful if in the meantime you could think about any questions you want to ask for the common discussion, any topics you wish to be covered, and whether there is any material you are willing to tell the group about.

For example, it would be exciting to learn from those of you who are going through (have finished?) Baby Rudin and have studied Chapters I-IV how our dear Walter treats continuity through metric spaces, provided it is possible to compact the highly alluring lecture into our time limits. Of course, it would be great to hear about any other topic you find useful.

There are also updates to the MAT157 Resources section of the ut.umu page, where the Companion Notes to PMA by Professor Evelyn Silvia have been added.

I am looking forward to seeing you today.

Good luck to all of you who have a midterm today.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: 20161018 UT MAT240: Past Midterms
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I hope most of you plan or in the progress of a good night sleep.

I certainly do.

This email is just to notify you that I have added 4 past MAT240 midterms for morning preparation.

Moreover, two sincere and lively comments have been added to the Comments section at the end of the page.

Good night, and good luck.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: 20161017 UT MAT240: 20161018 Midterm Resources
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I hope you have had a productive and refreshing weekend, so that tomorrow you get to grips and fully engage with the midterm exam.

A table with the problems from Friedberg et al, recommended by Professor Meinrenken since the beginning of the term, is now up on the ut.umu page.

You may also find the link to Terry Tao's LA course webpage in the same section, where sample and actual midterms with solutions are given.

I wish you good luck and lucid state of mind tomorrow.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: 20161014 UT Math Academic Experience: CUMC Talks
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I am very grateful to all of you who have come today for a series of fascinating talks by Zachary Karry, Angela Wu and Calder Morton-Ferguson (by the way, today, Saturday 15, is Calder's birthday).

From the Leech lattice, Hadwider-Nelson and beyond, there is a trove of known and unknown results awaiting our attention.

There are also happy news: Lola Bradford, Phil Blakey and Jessica (澄瑾) Liu have expressed their interest in joining our sessions.

I would be happy to hear any reflections, opinions and suggestions you might have regarding today's talks or sessions in general. For example, which talk today did you like most?

There are also updates on the ut.umu page for linear algebra, where some resources from George M. Bergman and Terry Tao have been added, all from the courses taught based on Friedberg et al.

I wish you a restful and productive weekend.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: 20161014 UT MAT157/MAT240: CUMC Talks
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I am grateful to all of you who have promptly reacted to the quick questionnaire either in person or by mail.

Out of 6 of those who replied, 6 wish to go or at least check out the talks.

I am looking forward to seeing you tomorrow at 16:30 in BA2135.

If you have any questions, comments or suggestions, please contact me, it would be extremely refreshing to hear what you think.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: 20161012 UT MAT157/MAT240: Updates
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

This is a follow-up to the announcement made earlier.

The curator of recognized study groups has confirmed that attending the CUMC talks organized by the Math Union on Friday at 16:30 in BA2135 counts as an academic experience eligible for CCR.

You can learn more about the talks on the MU website.

Since I am responsible for registering the participants of the study group attending the academic experience events, I must be present at either the study session or the CUMC talks to make the session or the academic experience recognized.

Thus, I would be grateful to hear your opinions on whether you would prefer to go to the talks or have a study session. To make it easier for you to reply and save some time for math, please choose one of the following options and write me an email with its one-letter code:

(s) Study Session (t) CUMC Talks

There are several members whose exams overlap with the study session this Friday. It is fine if you leave a bit early or come a bit late, provided you still find value in the session or talks.

Moreover, there are three talks, each lasting 20 minutes, and, if most of us decide to go to the talks, you can come to any one of those to make it count as an academic experience.

I am looking forward to hearing from you as soon as possible.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: 20161012 UT MAT157/MAT240: Notices
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I am writing to remind you that this Friday, October 14, we are going to have our second meeting in B026(seminar room), Bahen, at 16:10.

There are several updates this week.

First, Yooveshen Mooroogen, who decided to join our sessions, has suggested a list of recommended problems from Spivak as given in the MAT157 syllabus of 2012-2013. The table adapted from the syllabus has been published on the ut.umu page.

Secondly, ACE of UToronto got back to me about the request of reserving B026 for our sessions. In order to have such a privilege, we need to recognize our group with ULife first. The exact procedure will be investigated in detail after the midterms; there are several options available. For example, we may try to collaborate with Math Union. I will contact Angela shortly.

Finally, there are several talks organized by the Math Union at the time of our meeting on Friday, from 16:30. The topics include the following:

  • Why Some Sequences are More Special than Others by Calder Morton-Ferguson
  • The Chromatic Number of the Plane and the Axiom of Choice by Angela Wu
  • Sphere Packing and the Baffling Properties of the $$E_8$$ and Leech Lattices by Zachary Karry

If there is any interest, I will find out whether this may count as an academic experience in the context of CCR. If not, it sounds interesting anyway. Please let me know what you think.

If you intend to come earlier than 16:10 on Friday, the schedule on ACE for B026 shows that the room is going to be vacant after 15:00.

If you have any resources relevant to our agenda, for example lecture outlines from any week, please let me know and I will post them on the ut.umu page. Please also take a look at the MAT240 course page, where several bonus problems have been already posted.

I am looking forward to seeing you on Friday.

Onwards!

– sasha

item.title: UT MAT157: First Session
item.dc:creator: umu
item.description:
Team,

I am grateful to all of you who has come today and made the session productive despite some element of chaos which is often present in introductory meetings. And thank you for all the suggestions – they would definitely help us make our time together worthwhile.

One of the questions raised in the session was about the combination of training for MAT157 and MAT240 in one session. Everyone is free to choose any topic or problem to go through during the session, but I do think it is necessary to have the topic of the main discussion in mind before each session. My suggestion is to split officially the current time period in half, and devote one half to analysis and one half to algebra.

This would allow us to have a clear focus for a set period of time. As Fiona proposed, it would be great to devote some time in the beginning of each corresponding session to a quick recap of the week lectures, since this will give us a headstart with problems, hopefully identify the gaps in our knowledge and understanding as well as unite our efforts in a coherent discussion interesting for us all. If you have the outlines of lectures in any format or want to write them, please write me an email.

Alan expressed interest in reserving B026 as our base for the future sessions. I will write to ACE as soon as possible.

Matthew also suggested to create a Facebook group to spread information. If there is a demand and there are volunteers to look after the page, I am happy if you get involved with it, but would like to keep the logs of the sessions, announcements and resources on the umu website. For those of you who are new, please be aware there is a Facebook chat in which most of the instantaneous communication takes place.

If you want anything to be posted on the ut.umu page, please feel free to contact me.

Unfortunately, not every person who has participated today has written me an email. Registering is important if you want to obtain CCR after attending at least 4 sessions and having 1 academic experience.

The academic experience is supposed to add to our knowledge and academic skills development, and may involve various activities. We may book a mathematical (or any other, if there is a demand) research consultation, visit office hours of the beloved Joe Repka and Eckhard Meinrenken, a tutoring centre or a TA, or we may attend a workshop in the library. Please write what you think suits you best by email or in the Facebook chat.

If you had not already emailed me but attended the session, I would be grateful if you could fill the following form to register the attendance and send it by email from your mail.utoronto.ca address:

  1. First Name
  2. Are there any specific topics you want to go through in the next session, other than the content of the most recent lectures?
  3. What rules would you like the group to follow?
  4. Do you want your name to appear publicly in the register? If not, you may choose a nickname to be used instead. Currently, almost all names are listed in full. If you want to replace your name with something else, please drop me an email.

I am looking forward to hearing from you.

Onwards!

— sasha
